holdings.text: The question whether sanction under section 197 was necessary for instituting proceedings against the appellant on charges of conspiracy and of bribery, is concluded by the decisions of the Judicial Committee in H. H. B. Gill V. The King 1 and Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King 1 , and must be answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: These are the two points that arise for determination in his appeal. The question whether sanction under section 197 was necessary for instituting proceedings against the appellant on charges of conspiracy and of bribery, is concluded by the decisions of the Judicial Committee in H. H. B. Gill V. The King 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concluded by binding precedents of the Judicial Committee in H.H.B. Gill v. The King and Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King

holdings.text: The question whether there was contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code and a denial or fair trial must, for the reasons already given, be answered in the affirmative, and the conviction of the appellant set aside on that ground.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether there was contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code and a denial or fair trial must, for the reasons already given, be answered in the affirmative, and the conviction of the appellant set aside on that ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies the same reasoning as for other appellants regarding violation of section 257 and denial of opportunity to examine witnesses

holdings.text: We think that this complaint is well-founded.

anchor.surface_text: We think that this complaint is well-founded. By its judgment, dated 23rd April, 1948, the Federal Court decided that the order of the Tribunal, dated 8th April, 1946, declining to issue process for the witnesses mentioned in the list, dated 27th March, 1946, was in contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code, that the evidence of those witnesses would be material for refutation of the charges of both conspiracy and bribery, and that accordingly the appellants should be granted an opportunity to examine those witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Federal Court's finding of contravention of section 257 CrPC in initial trial and extends to overall vitiation

holdings.text: On this order, the only question that has to be decided is whether the appellants got such an opportunity when the appeal was re-heard in pursuance of the order of remand. ... the appellants did not get reasonable opportunity due to High Court delays making witnesses untraceable not their fault.

anchor.surface_text: On this order, the only question that has to be decided is whether the appellants got such an opportunity when the appeal was re-heard in pursuance of the order of remand. The important point to be noted is that by reason of the order of the High Court, dated 2nd August, 1948, the appeal was not taken up for hearing immediately as it ought to have been, and that it was only on 8th May, 1951, that it was possible for the appellants to take steps in the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delays from High Court adjournment and historical circumstances prevented tracing witnesses; fault lies with court process, not appellants

holdings.text: Whatever one may think of the merits of the appellants contention, they cannot be convicted without an opportunity being given to them to present their evidence, and that having been denied to them, there has been no fair trial, and the conviction of the appellants, S. K. Dutt, J. K. Bose and P. C. Ghose, cannot stand.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever one may think of the merits of the appellants contention, they cannot be convicted without an opportunity being given to them to present their evidence, and that having been denied to them, there has been no fair trial, and the conviction of the appellants, S. K. Dutt, J. K. Bose and P. C. Ghose, cannot stand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Denial of opportunity to rebut prosecution case via material defense witnesses constitutes no fair trial

holdings.text: it is essential that rules of procedure designed to ensure justice, should be scrupulously followed, and Courts should be jealous in seeing that there is no breach of them.

anchor.surface_text: The result may be unfortunate. But it is essential that rules of procedure designed to ensure justice, should be scrupulously followed, and Courts should be jealous in seeing that there is no breach of them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rules are mandatory to ensure justice; courts must guard against breaches

holdings.text: As admittedly three of them are real, it would be unsafe to act on the view that the others must be fictitious, and if they are real persons who could not be examined for no fault of the appellants, grave injustice would result in the accused being condemned without the evidence of these witnesses having been taken.

anchor.surface_text: But by that time, the situation had undergone a radical change. ... As admittedly three of them are real, it would be unsafe to act on the view that the others must be fictitious

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presence of real witnesses precludes assuming others fictitious; condemning without their evidence causes grave injustice
